title-group.article-title: Kinematics and workspace analysis of a novel 3-DOF parallel manipulator with virtual symmetric plane

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Ketao Zhang, King’s College London, Strand London, WC2R 2LS, UK. Email: ketao.zhang@kcl.ac.uk

abstract.p: This article presents a novel 3-DOF parallel manipulator extracted from an origami fold in the context of mechanisms. The parallel manipulator consists of a base, a platform and four chain-legs that connect the platform to base through revolute joints. Each chain-leg contains a closed-loop sub-chain, which is spherical 6R linkage with symmetrical angle lengths. The geometry of the parallel manipulator is revealed according to the configuration design and specifics of the origami fold. This leads to unravelling of the symmetric plane which is determined by the common points of spherical 6R linkages in the four chain-legs. Based on geometric approach, the solutions for both inverse and forward kinematics are derived and the reachable workspace is then analyzed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Parallel mechanisms developed from the original structure of Gough–Stewart platform1,2 with specified degrees of freedom (DOFs) have been extensively studied.3,4 In comparison with serial mechanisms, parallel mechanisms generally have higher stiffness and accuracy, and have been used in a wide variety of applications such as motion simulators, industry robots and nano-manipulators. Particularly, parallel manipulators with limited DOFs attracted more interest owing to their simplified structures with fewer links and actuators leading to lower costs. Hunt5 presented the kinematic structures towards in-parallel manipulators and proposed the 3-RPS parallel manipulator with mixed DOFs. Claver6 proposed the well-known 3-DOF translational parallel manipulator, Delta robot which has wide applications in industrial robots. Ceccarelli7 presented a 3-DOF parallel manipulator in which each chain-leg has four-bar parallelogram linkage employing spherical joints as closed-loop subchain and investigated the suitable formulation for the forward kinematics. Tsai et al.8 presented a 3-DOF translational parallel manipulator that employs only revolute joints and each of the chain-leg contains a planar four-bar parallelogram. Liu and Wang9 proposed a family of 3-DOF fully-parallel manipulators in which parallelogram is used to construct the kinematic chains leading to rotational output motion and improvement of system stiffness. Gogu10,11 investigated the structural synthesis approach of fully-isotropic parallel manipulators with translational motion and Schönflies motion based on theory of linear transformations. Planar closed-loops including monomobile, bimobile and trimobile loop are integrated in the complex chain-legs. These contributions dedicate to parallel manipulators especially that consist of certain closed-loop sub-chains as part of chain-legs in purpose of fine-turned performance.

The early design methods for parallel mechanisms, which devoted to particular applications were mainly based on intuition and experiences.12,13 The systematic structure synthesis approaches and design procedures for parallel manipulators were developed by introducing mathematical and geometrical tools such as screw theory,14–16 group theory,17 Grassmann geometry18 and linear transformations.19 Recently, a new way of identifying parallel mechanisms was proposed based on the concept of artimimetics.20,21 This aroused substantial interest in mechanisms inspired by cartons and origami folds. Winder et al.22 classified pop-up mechanisms and use planar and spherical kinematics in engineering to model pop-up paper mechanisms. Zhang et al.23 presented a three-spherical kinematic chain based parallel manipulator, which is extracted from an origami fold and investigated the singularity of the parallel manipulator by examining the disposition of constraints in terms of screw theory.

This article presents a novel 3-DOF parallel manipulator, which can be extracted from a cube origami fold with pregrooved creases in the context of mechanisms. The configuration design of the origami fold is introduced and the evolved parallel manipulator consists of four identical chain-legs, which connect the platform to the base with revolute joints. Each of the chain-legs contains a closed-loop sub-chain, which is symmetrical spherical 6R linkage. The geometry of the parallel manipulator is addressed and the symmetric plane that formed by the common points in each chain-leg is derived. The kinematics of the parallel manipulator is analyzed and the reachable workspace of the manipulator is then obtained.

sec.title: A parallel manipulator extracted from an origami fold
sec.p:
The concept of mechanisms is often embodied in artefacts where they exist in the form of origami fold of cardboard that appear in many occasions. Having had the concept of a mechanism, an origami fold can be taken as a mechanism when considering panels as links and creases, which link the adjacent paper panels as revolute joints. A typical example made from flat card is the Sarrus mechanism that consists of six bars where groups of three revolute joints are parallel or concurrent.24 The sarrus linkage with parallel revolute joints in perpendicular directions made from flat card and the corresponding kinematic model are illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Sarrus linkage with parallel revolute joints.

A cardboard in square shape is illustrated as origami fold in Figure 2(a), which is creased along two diagonals and horizontal center line. The three creases have the common point Ai which is the center of the square flat card and divide the cardboard into six panels symmetrically. All the panels are in isosceles right triangle shape and the panels li1, li2 and li6 are the mirror of panels li3, li4 and li5 respectively. A T-shaped cardboard in Figure 2(b) consists of six square cardboard in which four of the creased flat cards 1, 3, 5 and 6 are joined to another two square flat cards 2 and 4 in the manner that no creased cardboard are connected in consecutive. Figure 2.
A T-shaped cardboard formed with square flat card.

A new structural origami fold in Figure 3 is constructed by properly erecting the T-shaped cardboard in Figure 2. The erection process involves rotating the flat card about the crease lines and fixing flaps 7, 8 and 9 to panel 4 and 2, respectively. Figure 3.
An origami fold from the T-shaped cardboard.

The diagram of a new parallel manipulator in Figure 4 is a mapping21 from the origami fold in Figure 3. The parallel manipulator consists of a base, a platform, and four identical chain-legs that connect the platform to the base with revolute joints. Figure 4.
The new parallel manipulator with four identical chain-legs.

The base is labeled b and the platform p. Both the base and platform are in square shape and described by parameter r, the inscribed circle radius of the square plates. The four chain-legs labeled as CL1, CL2, CL3 and CL4, and each chain-leg contains a closed-loop subchain, which is spherical 6R linkage with symmetric structure. The revolute joints attached to the base are labeled Bi (i = 1, 2, 3, 4) and that attached to the platform are labeled Pi. The axes of the revolute joints attached to platform and base are coplanar and align to edges of the two square plates, respectively.

sec.title: Geometric analysis and symmetric plane of the parallel manipulator
sec.p:
Looking closely at the square cardboard with precuts and pre-grooved creases in Figure 2(a) and its erected configuration in Figure 3, it is taken as spherical 6R linkage when mapping the origami fold to the parallel manipulator in Figure 4. The axes of the six revolute joints intersect at a common point Ai (i = 1, 2, 3 and 4). The geometry of the spherical 6R linkage is characterized by the angles between adjacent joint axes which are denoted as αij (j = 1, 2, … , 6) in Figure 5. Figure 5.
A spherical 6R linkage with symmetrical structure.

Since the 6R linkage is a mapping of the square cardboard in Figure 2(a), the angles αij are determined as αi1 = αi4 = 90°, αi2 = αi3 = αi5 = αi6 = 45°. This leads to the symmetrical structure of the spherical 6R linkage. The spherical 6R linkage acts as a closed-loop subchain and form hybrid chain-leg together with the other two revolute joints which connect the 6R linkage to the base and platform. The link li1 is connected to the base by revolute joint which axis is perpendicular to AiBi and aligns with the edge of base. The trajectory of each common point Ai is circular arc with points Bi as the center and AiBi as radius with respect to the base. At the other end, link li4 is connected to platform by revolute joint with axis perpendicular to AiPi and aligning with the edge of the platform. The trajectory of each common point Ai is circular arc with points Pi as the center and AiPi as radius with respect to the platform. All the loci of the common points Ai (i = 1, 2, 3 and 4) are illustrated in Figure 6(a). Consider the symmetrical structure of the spherical 6R linkage in each chain-leg, the radii of the two circular arcs of common point Ai corresponding to each chain-leg are equal, meaning that AiBi = AiPi = ra. Further, ra equals to r in this specific parallel manipulator since the inscribed circle radii of the square flat cards in Figure 2 are equal. Figure 6.
Loci of the common points and the symmetric plane: (a) loci of the common points with respect to the base and platform; (b) characteristics of the symmetric plane.

In the parallel manipulator, the circles with centers B1 and B3 and that with centers B2 and B4 are located in two vertical planes which are perpendicular to the base and determined by ΔObA1A3 and ΔObA2A4. B1B3 and B2B4 are the lines of centers of the two pair of circles respectively. Similarly, the circles with centers P1 and P3 and that with centers P2 and P4 are located in two planes which are perpendicular to the platform and determined by ΔOpA1A3 and ΔOpA2A4. P1P3 and P2P4 are the lines of centers of each pair of circles. A1A3 is the common line of the two planes defined by the ΔObA1A3 and ΔOpA1A3 and A2A4 is the common line of the two planes defined by the ΔObA2A4 and ΔOpA2A4 in Figure 6.

The front view of the loci of common point A1 and A3 is illustrated in Figure 6(b), G1, G3 and O’ are the mid-points of A1A1', A3A3' and ObOp, respectively. This reveals that B1G1 = P1G1 and both B1G1 and P1G1 are perpendicular to the common line A1A3. The same result comes at point G3, meaning that B3G3 = P3G3 and A1A3 is the common perpendicular of B3G3 and P3G3. This follows that lines align with B1B3, P1P3 and A1A3 meet at a common point and the common line A1A3 is perpendicular to B1P1 and B3P3. Since Ob and Op are the mid-points of B1B3 and P1P3, it can be obtained that ObOp is parallel to B1P1 and B3P3. Thus, the projection of common line A1A3 on the plane formed by B1B3 and P1P3 pass through O′ and is perpendicular to ObOp. In other words, ObOp is perpendicular to the plane π formed by O′ and the common line A1A3.
Similarly, the examine of the circle with centers B2, P2, B4 and P4 revels that ObOp is perpendicular to the plane π which passes through O′ and contains the common line A2A4.

Hence, the two common lines A1A3 and A2A4 are coplanar and located in the plane π which passes through all the mid-points of BiPi (i = 1, 2, 3 and 4). It implies that the common points Ai determine the symmetric plane π of the parallel manipulator. This follows that joint axes passing through Bi and Pi are symmetrical with respect to the plane π. Consider the symmetric structure of the spherical 6R linkage and the symmetry of the joint axes passing through Bi and Pi in the parallel manipulator, the joint axes Ri2 an Ri5 of the spherical 6R linkage locate in the symmetric plane.

The origin of global coordinate frame {XYZ} is attached to the base at point Ob, the center of the base in Figure 7. The X-axis is collinear with ObB1, Y-axis is aligning to ObB2 and Z-axis is normal to the base and pointing upward. For each chain-leg, the origin of local coordinate frame {xiyizi} is located at Bi. The xi-axis is collinear with ObBi, yi-axis is aligning to the joint axis passing Bi and zi-axis is parallel to Z-axis following the right hand rule. The angle βi is measured from xi-axis to BiAi. Figure 7.

sec.title: Kinematic analysis of the parallel manipulator
sec.p: The output link li4 of the spherical 6R linkage embedded in each chain-leg has three independent rotational DOFs with respect to the base link li1. This reveals that the spherical 6R linkage implements equivalent motion of a commonly used spherical joint in terms of equivalence of motion screws. Under such condition, the equivalent motion screws of the hybrid chain-leg which consists of a spherical 6R linkage and two revolute joints attached to the base and platform form a five-system. Reciprocally, the constraints of each chain-leg can be calculated from the motion screws.23 It reveals that each chain-leg exerts one constraint force which passes through the common point Ai and locates in the symmetric plane π.

The four chain-legs of the parallel manipulator exert four constraint forces in total on the platform. Generally, the four constraint forces are coplanar without common point and form a 3-system. The basis of the constraint system consists of one couple and two forces. Hence, one rotation about the axis perpendicular to the symmetric plane π and translations along axes located in the symmetric plane are constrained and the platform has three DOFs. In other words, the translational motion direction is perpendicular to the symmetric plane and the rotational axes are located in the symmetric plane π.

sec.title: Inverse kinematics
sec.p: As illustrated in the kinematic model of the parallel manipulator with equivalent chain-legs in Figure 7, the origin of the moving coordinate frame {UVW} is attached to the platform at point Op, the center of the plate. The U- and V-axis are collinear with OpP1 and OpP2 respectively and W-axis is normal to the platform following the right-hand rule. The origin of local coordinate frame {uiviwi} is located at Pi. The ui-axis is collinear with OpPi, vi-axis is aligning to the axis passing point Pi and wi-axis is parallel to W-axis. The vector p is a normal of the platform and passing through center point Op.

The angle βi measured from xi to the lower arm BiAi can be selected as the actuated joint angle. The angle γi is measured from the ui-axis to upper arm PiAi as shown in Figure 7. Since the parallel manipulator is symmetrical through plane π defined by the four common points, position vector Op lies in the vertical plane determined by Z-axis and the projection of normal vector in XOY plane. The angle between Z-axis and ObOp is denoted as θ, the angle between Z-axis and normal vector p is defined as θ and that between X-axis and the projection of normal vector p on the base is denoted as δ. The symmetric structure of the parallel manipulator leads to θ = 2ψ.

For inverse kinematics, the position and orientation of the platform with respect to the {XYZ} coordinate frame is given and the purpose is to find the input joint angles. sec.title: Forward kinematics
sec.p: For the novel parallel manipulator with four chain-legs, only three of the four input angles βi corresponding to the chain-legs are independent.

When the three angles β1, β2 and β3 are considered as independent input angles, the location of the point Ai (i = 1, 2, 3) can be determined. The angles γi measured from ui-axis to PiAi take the same value of βi (i = 1, 2, 3) respectively because of the symmetry of the manipulator through the plane π in which common points Ai lie.
As aforementioned, ObOp is perpendicular to the symmetrical plane π and the intersection point M is coincide with the mid-point O’ of ObOp. Thus, ObOp expressed in the global frame is (17)xAm=yBm=zCm

sec.title: Workspace analysis of the parallel manipulator
sec.p: The workspace of a manipulator is defined as the entirety of positions that an identified point of the end-effector can reach.25,26 This section addresses the reachable workspace which refers to the domain where the reference point of the 3-DOF parallel manipulator can be reached.

Consider the symmetrical structure of the parallel manipulator in Figure 4, the input angles βi of the base joint which is taken as actuated joint can vary from 0 to +π in the local coordinate frame. Since the radii of base and platform r and the equivalent link length ra are equal for this specific parallel manipulator, the two design parameters can be set arbitrarily according the practical requirements.

The constraints for the workspace of the manipulator can be derived from the extreme position of the platform where one of the four chain-legs is fully deployed as the case in Figure 8. At this extreme position, the chain-leg CL3 is fully unfolded and all the revolute joints are coplanar and chain-leg CL1 is folded and the joint axes passing B1 and P1 are collinear. The two coincident points B1 and P1 together with the other two points B3 and P3 form an equilateral triangle. It implies that Ob is the projection point of B3 on the base plane. Hence, the possible domain of xp and yp is (21)-0.5r<xp<0.5r,-0.5r<yp<0.5r Figure 8.
Extreme position of the platform.

Further, the vertexes Qi of the platform keeps upward side of the base and the following constraints are derived, that (22){zq1=--2Cm(Am+Bm+Dm)Am2+Bm2+Cm2≥0zq2=--2Cm(-Am+Bm+Dm)Am2+Bm2+Cm2≥0zq3=--2Cm(-Am-Bm+Dm)Am2+Bm2+Cm2≥0zq4=--2Cm(Am-Bm+Dm)Am2+Bm2+Cm2≥0

Hence, the reachable workspace of the 3-DOF parallel manipulator in Figure 4 can be derived by calculating the domain within which the center point Op of the platform can reach according to the solutions of kinematics. When the design parameters are given as r = ra = 1, the reachable workspace of the parallel manipulator is calculated and shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.
The reachable workspace of the 3-DOF parallel manipulator with r = ra = 1. DOF: degree of freedom.

The 3-DOF parallel manipulator shown in Figure 4 contains only revolute joints and is symmetric about the plane π. The revolute joints which have full range motion without physical constraints from structure of themselves lead to minimum restriction in design and large reachable workspace of the parallel manipulator. This parallel manipulator with above advantages can be adopted as constant velocity joint to sustain heavy payload transmission resorting to its parallel and symmetric structure. Further, this parallel manipulator can be used to replace the conventional satellite tracking mechanisms since the uniqueness of the forward kinematics.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article presented a new 3-DOF parallel manipulator which employs only revolute joints and has mixed motion mode with two rotational DOFs and one translational DOF. The parallel manipulator is a mapping of an origami fold and each chain-leg consists of a spherical 6R linkage and two revolute joints which connect the 6R linkage to the platform and base. The geometry of the parallel manipulator reveals that the four common points of the spherical 6R linkage are coplanar and determine a symmetric plane of the parallel manipulator. The solutions for both the inverse and forward kinematics are derived and these solutions demonstrate that in general, there is only one unique pose the manipulator can assume for a given set of input joint angles. The reachable workspace of the parallel manipulator is then obtained and the distinct characteristics of this parallel manipulator lead to potential applications.
